description: Unknown, 1827 US, presumably fanciful variant of sock (“to hit”); compare contemporary fanciful American coinages.
Various speculative etymologies have been suggested, such as corruption of doxology, due to this occurring at the end of church worship, hence “finality”.

entries.meaning: (US, slang, dated) A hard hit, a knockout or finishing blow, or conclusive argument.
examples: He’ll come off as badly as a feller I once hit a sledge hammer lick over the head—a real sogdolloger.

entries.meaning: (US, slang, dated) Something large or otherwise exceptional; a whopper.
examples: Hey, Al, thought I'd call you from the locker room out here at Green Hills. Just made a sockdolager hole in one! A hole in one, Al! (etc.)

entries.meaning: (US, fishing) A combination of two hooks which close upon each other, by means of a spring, as soon as the fish bites.
